newsitem.title: USA: Most emerging debt follows U.S. Treasuries rally.
newsitem.headline: Most emerging debt follows U.S. Treasuries rally.

text.p: Most Brady bonds rose higher on the coattails of a rally in the U.S. Treasury market on Friday, traders said.
"The momentum is pretty good across the board and we had a nice rally in the U.S. Treasury market," one trader said. "Our market is lagging that rally."
Brazil "C" bonds gained 1/4 to stand at 79-1/4 bid, but higher price talk on its upcoming Eurobond prevented a more-significant rise, traders said.
In other major Latin issues, Argentina FRBs were unchanged at 93-1/4 bid, and Mexico Pars were up 5/8 at 75-1/8.
Peru spreads narrowed substantially. FLRBs were about 18 basis points narrower, up 1-1/4 at 57-7/8 bid. PDIs narrowed about nine basis points, with their price up 1/2 at 63-1/4.
Anticipation of strong economic growth figures for April gave players a reason to get back into Peru paper, traders said.

"Mainly, Peru was lagging the rest of the market," a Brady trader said. "The spreads against the majors were too wide, and we thought that Peru could easily tighten 30 basis points. Today was the day Peru caught up."
Interest in the country came from small accounts in the United States and Latin America, the trader said.
"The momentum is pretty good. I think Peru could continue tightening a little bit," he said.
Venezuela Brady debt widened amid profit taking, traders said. News of a new 10-year $315 million Eurobond had spurred buying of the country's Bradys on Wednesday.
Venezuela FLIRBs were off 1/4 at 91-1/4 bid, and Discounts were off 1/2 at 86-1/2 bid.
"We tightened quite a bit yesterday and we just gave it all back today," a Venezuela Brady trader said. "There's no real fundamental news other than the launching of the global."
Elsewhere, Ecuador Pars climbed 5/8 to 45-3/8, Poland PDIs rose 7/8 to 84-1/8 and dollar-denominated Russian Vnesh loans were up 3/8 at 86-1/4.
U.S. Treasuries rose on technical factors and benign economic data releases, market analysts said. The benchmark 30-year bond was up 24/32 to yield 6.92 percent.
